What exactly are realistic premiums? Not community rated at all? There are people that insurance companies simply refuse to cover. Apparently including good samaritans who donate a kidney. Others get their by having the misfortune of having been sick, or born with some genetic flaw.

Of course, the West has a much higher proportion of highly educated people - so I would expect people on the whole to be more rational (though not in America!) - but that has nothing to do with differences between East and West.

I think Indians offer a lot of dietary advice too both for the successful fertilization of an egg and then for the embryo to turn into the right kid of baby -- meaning male of course.

I remember an aunt -- a first cousin and contemporary of my mom -- who had a lot of trouble conceiving. I have no idea whatsoever how even little me 30 years back had come to notice their ill luck. Clearly elders must have been discussing the matter in front of me -- or is it that even Indian kids know that every couple is supposed to have kids?

And I remember from dim recesses of memory that the lady was advised that she should have full bananas which she should gulp at a stretch or some such unusual way of eating it for ensuring kids -- and a lot else religious mumbo jumbo of course.

Astonishingly enough, she did manage to conceive after may be a decade of trying -- don't know if the success was caused by trial and error or some medical means.

Anyway the aunt is dead now [and I won't add the superfluous 'may her soul rest in peace' here] and the spooky thing is she died within a day or two of my father dying around half a decade ago.

She was a frequent sufferer -- from chronic asthma perhaps. A strange life now that I think about it.

I have a bouquet of memories of her -- if I was so talented, I would have written a novel about a kid growing up and she would surely be a character in that novel.

Is it just me who sometimes looks back at the imperfect memories of 30 years gone by?

A very good summary of the situation indeed. The interesting thing about Delhi is with the advent of the Metro the buses tend to be much less crowded than they used to be. And there are a few more AC buses. But people have made their preference clear. Now if only the metro could keep up with the demand. One additional problem though is that public transport (including the metro) has necessarily got to be cheap or people can't use it, so crowding is part of the economic calculation. The main costs are not labor so that 15c cheapest fare cannot possibly come close to covering the cost of running the metro system if it isn't full.

Leaving aside the class warfare insinuations of the BRT corridor, the fact is that it is badly planned. it's in the middle lane, but there are no bridges or subways for the users to reach it. So they run across the crowded car lanes making the problem worse.

To motivate private car users to switch to public transportation, it is not sufficient to only make private transportation unattractive, but also to make public transportation attractive. The Delhi Metro and BRT are very good ventures but they are failing to address the high number of passengers who are using them or want to use them. The Delhi public transport systems are already running at beyond their capacities, even at the non-peak hours which points to insufficient planning and infrastructure. It cannot be expected for more people to start using public transportation if they are already running beyond capacity since it does create more hassle rather than being time savers as expected. In this scenario, private car owners who can afford it prefer to spend more time inside the comfort of their cars than in the Metro or buses. Running at over-capacity also tends to makes public transportation unsafe, which adds to the negatives.
Delhi is indeed including AC buses which are more comfortable and are reasonable priced but they are very infrequent and do not sufficiently cater to the needs of the general public.
What is required is a more robust system which alleviates the discomfort of the buses - for example, increasing the number of buses (both AC and non AC) and charging more fare to cover the costs of the new fleet - and provides realtime schedule and updates for buses and metro to be a better time-saver.

It is almost humorous when American regulators and legislators are investigating the Libor rigging but not the "Prime Rate" rigging that has been going on for decades.

 The "Prime Rate" is really much more relevant to the U.S.  during the past 50 years.  Until more recently the Libor is not even in the picture in U.S. consumer credit. Most credit cards and consumer loans are/were more tied to the "prime rate" which was defined as the "the rate the banks charged to the banks' most credit worthy customers, such as the AAA companies".  Since the late 1980's the banks have been systematically rigging the prime rate by gradually increasing it over time so that it is now almost 300 basis points (3%) over the real "prime rate", i.e., what the banks really charged AAA companies such as Exxon and Johnson and Johnson.  This is the banks way of picking everyone's pocket without permission to the extend of billions and billions of dollars every year.  It is the biggest fraud in America.

Our government and the Federal Reserve actually are part of this scheme in that they redefined the definition of "Prime Rate" in the official publications rather than stopping the banks from doing this. You can check this out just by looking at the old publications from the Federal Reserve Interest Rate Series vs. the current ones.

Even attempts to correct this thru the legal system has been unsuccessful as the banks seem to have influence over the courts also (see Lum vs. Bank of America, et al).
